item.title: Bash Special Parameters
item.description: Special parameters are set by the shell to store information about aspects of its current state, such as the number of arguments and the exit code of the last command. Special parameters can only be referenced and cannot have it’s value assigned. Special parameters are: $*, $@, $#, $$, $!, $?, $0, $-, $_ Parameter Definition $* List of arguments (as a string) $@ List of arguments (as an array) $# Number of positional parameters $$ PID of the current shell $!

item.title: Additional Status for Vim With Powerline
item.description: Would you like to have more information displayed while reading files in VIM? Powerline is a great utility for that. item.title: Bash: Parameter Expansion (Substitution)
Alternatives to Top
item.description: Looking for alternatives to your usual top command? Here are some options. htop htop is based on ncurses and is compatible with most Linux (and Unix) systems. It’s also in most the official repos for most distros. Features: - Mouse clicks (due to ncurses) - Defaults to multi-CPU view - Memory shown in GB Website: http://hisham.hm/htop/ vtop vtop takes more of a graphical approach to top, while concentrating more on simplicity.

item.title: Bash - Command Substitution, Subshell and Codeblock
item.description: Bash - Command Substitution, Subshell and Codeblock Quick and simple differences between using $(..), (..) and {..;}. $(command) or `command` - Command substitution (the output of a command replaces the command name) and is executed in a subshell. Please give preference to $(..) for better readability ( command ) - Command list is executed in a subshell { command ;} - Command list is executed in the current shell Executing code
